Dear Mr. Harris:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of Staff
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 4/12/23, youth engaged in self-harm causing injury to their
arm. Youth was supposed to be on 5 minutes checks at this time
and have the bathroom door cracked open. Staff member in
charge did not follow appropriate precautions in place to prevent
this incident.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant/Administrator was interviewed face to face at
the facility on 4/14/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker.
Complainant reported there were multiple concerns noted in the
video review she completed of the night of Youth A’s self-harm
incident on 4/12/23. Complainant noted Youth A’s safety
precautions were not followed and staff did not complete interval
checks as needed for Youth A, Youth B or Youth C.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the hospital on
4/14/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Youth A prefers
pronouns They/Them and will be referenced as such throughout
the report. Youth A stated they were on 1:1 supervision from
November 2022 until recently. Youth A reported when they are on
1:1 supervision, there are 15-minute checks. However, when they
are not on 1:1 supervision, there are 5-minute checks. Youth A
reported they cannot have the door of their bedroom, or the door
of the bathroom fully closed. The bathroom door must remain
cracked, and the bedroom door must remain open. Youth A
refused to take their medications for 3 days and, as a result, they
did not sleep for 3 days. Youth A reported on 4/12/23, they went to
Hobby Lobby with Staff 3 and bought a craft kit. The craft kit had
paint by number, color by number and scratch art. Youth A
reported Staff 3 took the tools utilized for scratch art out of the kit
so Youth A wouldn’t harm themselves but failed to take the small
pencil sharpener out of the kit. Youth A reported they broke the
blade out of the pencil sharpener with the intention to use it to self-
harm. Youth A reported they were in the bathroom taking a bath
and the door was cracked. Youth A reported Staff 1 was assigned
to complete checks on them and believes he conducted 5-minute
checks as required. Youth A reported the first time Staff 1 checked
2

on them, he knocked on the door and asked if they were okay, to
which Youth A responded yes. Youth A reported the second time
Staff 1 checked on them, they did not respond right away so Staff
1 asked if they were okay again and Youth A responded no. Youth
A reported Staff 1 requested to come in the bathroom, which
Youth A agreed to. Youth A reported they used the blade to cut
their arms in the bathroom and Staff 1 retrieved towels to help
them clean up. Youth A reported their intention behind getting the
kit was not to self-harm, but their intention of going into the
bathroom that night was to self-harm. Youth A reported they did
not want to follow the safety precautions the facility clinician
provided after the incident, so Youth A went to the hospital for
treatment and assessment.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/18/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Chief Administrator sat
in on the interview as well. Staff 1 reported Youth A was in good
spirits on 4/12/23, but still refused to take their medications, which
was the third day in a row they had refused. Staff 1 reported Youth
A is on self-harm/suicide precautions which means they require 5-
minute checks, are not allowed access to objects they could use
to harm themselves, must have bedroom door open while inside,
and must have bathroom door cracked while inside. Staff 1
reported he and Staff 2 were in the home, but then Staff 2 left to
go assist with another crisis, so he was the only staff in the home
at the time Youth A self-harmed. Staff 1 reported he was not
comfortable being the only staff in the home, but the youth were
all in their rooms and things were calm, so he told Staff 2 he was
fine with it. Staff 1 reported Youth A requested to take a bath, so
Staff 1 opened the bathroom for them. Staff 1 reported Youth A
closed the door to undress, but Staff 1 made sure the door was
cracked after Youth A was in the bath. Staff 1 reported Youth A
took a bath for approximately 30-40 minutes, and he conducted 5-
minute checks on them during the entirety of the time they were in
the bathroom. Staff 1 reported during each check he conducted,
he knocked on the door and asked if Youth A was okay. Staff 1
reported Youth A responded “yes” each time except the last time
he checked, which was around 10:20 pm. Staff 1 said when he
checked at that time, the door to the bathroom was fully shut and
locked, which is not allowed. Staff 1 reported he was unsure when
Youth A fully shut the door. Staff 1 reported Youth A didn’t
respond at first, but then responded they were not okay. He
reported he asked Youth A if he could enter the bathroom, and
Youth A said he could. When Staff 1 entered, Youth A was fully
clothed laying on the floor with cuts up and down both of their
arms. Staff 1 took away the blade Youth A used to cut themselves
3

and checked to ensure there were no other tools they could use
for self-harm. Staff 1 then left the bathroom to go to the
medication room to get towels to help Youth A clean up. On the
way to the medication room, Staff 1 called Staff 2 and requested
she come back to the home because he needed assistance. Staff
1 brought towels back to Youth A and helped them clean their
wounds, then provided Youth A a blanket so they could sit in the
milieu. Staff 2 called Supervisor for assistance while Staff 1 was
attending to Youth A. Supervisor and on-call clinician came to the
home and attempted to allow Youth A to stay in the home with
additional safety precautions of taking medications and stripping
their room, but Youth A would not agree to the precautions, so
they went to the hospital instead. Staff 1 reported he was
specifically assigned to Youth A, so he was responsible for Youth
A’s 5-minute checks. If another staff were responsible for the 5-
minute checks, staff would write on the interval check logs a
different staff took over responsibility.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/18/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Chief Administrator sat
in on the interview as well. Staff 2 reported Youth A was in a
good mood on 4/12/23. Staff 2 reported Staff 3 left the home the
evening of 4/12/23 to handle a situation with another youth in the
home going AWOL. When Staff 3 did not come back to the house
for a while, Staff 2 reported she asked Staff 1 if she could leave to
go check on Staff 3 and Staff 1 agreed. Staff 2 reported she called
Staff 3 and Staff 3 stated she was dealing with a crisis with a
youth from another house on campus. Staff 2 reported she went to
Ceblek home to see if she could help. Staff 2 reported there was a
supervisor at Ceblek home with two youth and she stayed there in
case help was needed. Staff 2 reported no one instructed her or
asked her to help at Ceblek, and she went there by her own
choice. Staff 2 reported she came back to Renucci house when
Staff 1 called her and reported he needed help because Youth A
self-harmed. Staff 2 reported when she arrived at the home, she
called Supervisor to request assistance while Staff 1 attended to
Youth A.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/18/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Chief Administrator sat
in on the interview as well. Staff 3 reported she was the Shift
Team Lead during 2nd shift on 4/12/23. Staff 3 reported she took
Youth A to Hobby Lobby when Youth A did not want to eat dinner.
Staff 3 reported Youth A bought a craft kit, which included paint by
number, color by number and scratch art. Staff 3 reported she saw
the scratch tools in the kit and took those away so Youth A could
4

not use the tools for self-harm. Staff 3 reported she did not view
the contents of the craft kit or check if there was anything else
Youth A could use to harm themselves with because she
assumed the scratch tools were the only things in the kit that could
be utilized for self-harm. Staff 3 reported the home was within ratio
the night of 4/12/23, so she felt comfortable leaving Staff 1 and
Staff 2 in the home when she had to handle situations with
another youth in the home going AWOL as well a crisis with a
youth from another home on campus. Staff 3 reported Youth A
had a good day which they expressed by being sociable, talkative,
and laughing a lot. Staff 3 reported Youth A showed no warning
signs she was going to self-harm that night.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
4/18/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Chief
Administrator sat in on the interview as well. Supervisor
reported he, Staff 3 and two other staff were handling a situation
with a youth in crisis from another home when the crisis with
Youth A occurred. Supervisor received a call stating Youth A
harmed themselves, so he went to the home to view their injuries
and assess next steps. Supervisor reported he was on the phone
with the on-call manager and on-call clinician to determine Youth
A’s safety and next steps. When he arrived at the home, Youth A
was laying on the couch quietly. Youth A had a lot of shallow cuts
on their arms but was no longer bleeding. Youth A refused first aid
treatment. The on-call clinician was attempting to safety plan with
Youth A so Youth A could remain on campus. However, Youth A
refused to comply with the safety plan, so 911 was contacted and
an ambulance took Youth A to the hospital for further assessment
and treatment. Supervisor reported when he was in the home
earlier in the evening, everything seemed fine. Prior to this
incident, no one called him that night and requested additional
help, assistance, or support.
VIDEO REVIEWED:
Video footage from the night of 4/12/23 was reviewed. At 9:52 pm,
Staff 1 opens the bathroom door and Youth A enters the
bathroom. It can be heard on video the bathroom door shuts and
latches. Staff 1 walks away down the hallway and sits at the table
in the dining area. Staff 1 gets up from the table at 9:57 pm, enters
the staff bathroom, exits the bathroom, and sits back at the dining
room table. Staff 2 is seen leaving the home at 9:58 pm. Staff 1
remains at the dining room table until 10:03 pm when he gets up
and goes to the bathroom door. He knocks on the door and asks
Youth A if they are okay. Youth A responds “yes”. Staff 1 walked
away and sat back at the dining room table at 10:04 pm. Between
5

10:05pm-10:19pm, Staff 1 cleans up the table, goes to the staff
bathroom, speaks with Supervisor in the medication room and sits
at the dining room table. At 10:20 pm, Staff 1 goes to the
bathroom to check on Youth A. Staff 1 has to use a key to open
the bathroom door and he stands in the doorway talking to Youth
A for a minute. He then walks away and is seen typing on his
phone. He enters the medication room, exits with towels and
brings them to the bathroom. He goes to the medication room to
retrieve towels two more times over the next few minutes and the
third time, Staff 2 is with him. Youth A exits the bathroom at 10:31
pm and lays on the couch in the milieu with a blanket.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• DA Blodgett St. John’s Youth Supervision Procedure (rev.
6/2022) states staff will complete the Daily Observation
Record (DOR) for each youth they are responsible for. The
DOR will be handed off to a different staff when the
supervision responsibility changes. Staff must always keep
the DOR on their person and document the location of each
youth at varying intervals not to exceed 15 minutes.
Frequency of checks may be increased during precautions
or suicide status. Staff are responsible to always know
where youth are. During nighttime checks, staff must
observe the room to ensure youth are in their room and not
engaging in unsafe behavior.
• Youth A’s Behavior Observation Log dated 4/12/23. Staff 1
documented Youth A was in the bathroom at 9:40 pm,
which is not accurate per video footage reviewed. Staff 2
documented Youth A was in the bathroom at 9:45 pm,
which is not accurate per video footage reviewed. Staff 1
documented he checked on Youth A at 9:50 pm, 9:55 pm,
10:00 pm, 10:05 pm, 10:10 pm, 10:15 pm and 10:20 pm
while Youth was in the bathroom. According to video
footage reviewed, Staff 1 checked on Youth A at 10:03 pm
and 10:20 pm.
• Youth A’s Clinical Assessment for Precautions dated
1/13/23 & updated 4/9/23 states staff will monitor Youth A
and document supervision at least every 5 minutes from
3pm-8am due to self-harm risk and suicide risk. Bathroom
door must always be cracked so privacy can be maintained
but staff can still intervene. Remove all items from room
that can be used for self-harm.
6

• Staff 1 did not have any discipline records in his personnel
file prior to this incident. On 4/18/23, Staff 1 was terminated
from the facility due to violation of policies and procedures
surrounding falsification of documentation for youth checks
and not following Youth A’s precautions and safety plan,
which resulted in Youth A participating in self-injurious
behavior. Staff 1 completed Supervision and Ratio policy
training on 3/23/23.
• Staff 2 does not have any discipline records in her
personnel file. Staff completed Supervision Scenario
Training on 8/25/22 and Supervision and Ratio policy
training on 3/23/23.
• Staff 3 does not have any discipline records in her
personnel file. Staff 3 completed Supervision Scenario
Training on 8/25/22, Suicide Screening for Direct Care Staff
on 11/15/22, Supervision and Ratio policy training on
3/23/23 and Residential Team Behavior Observation
Report Training on 4/6/23.
Analysis The facility is found in violation as Staff 1 did not comply with
requirements surrounding completion of 5-minute checks,
bathroom door remaining cracked open and Staff 3 did not fully
check the craft kit to ensure there were no other items Youth A
could use to self-harm. As a result, Youth A harmed themselves.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
• Staff need to contemplate all aspects of leaving the home
to help or handle another crisis prior to leaving. Staff should
take into account youth precautions, number of youth in the
home, number of staff in the home, gender of staff in the
home and seniority of staff in the home prior to voluntarily
making decisions to go to another home they are not
assigned to. If there is not a crisis where help is requested
elsewhere, staff should remain in their assigned home to
ensure safety of youth as well as other staff.
• Youth A’s precautions plan should include specifications to
check items Youth A purchases on outings to ensure there
is nothing they can harm themselves with. Current
precaution plan specifically says, “remove all items from
room that can be used for self-harm”.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR2022C0328030 dated 7/7/22; CAP approved 7/27/22
SIR2021C0128038 dated 7/20/21; CAP approved 9/13/21

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(d) Storage of medications.
Violation Additional Finding of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation On 4/12/23, staff member left medication room door open and
unattended.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/18/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Chief Administrator sat
in on the interview as well. Staff 1 reported he retrieved towels
from the medication room to help Youth A clean up the cuts on
their arm. Staff 1 admitted he did not close the medication room
door after retrieving the towels. Staff 1 reported all the youth were
in their rooms and Youth A’s situation was an emergency, so he
wanted to be able to access the room quickly if necessary.
VIDEO REVIEWED
Video footage from the night of 4/12/23 was reviewed. Staff 1
enters the medication room at 10:21 pm and leaves the
medication room door open. Staff 2 let Youth C into the other
bathroom at 10:25 pm. When she walks down the hallway back
towards the milieu, she closes the medication room door at 10:26
pm.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• DA Blodgett St. John’s Medication Storage Procedure
states medications must always be double locked. The
locked medication cart must be stored in a locked room
when not in use.
• Staff 1 did not have any discipline records in his personnel
file prior to this incident. On 4/18/23, Staff 1 was terminated
from the facility due to violation of policies and procedures
surrounding falsification of documentation for youth checks
and not following Youth A’s precautions and safety plan,
which resulted in Youth A participating in self-injurious
behavior. Staff 1 completed Residential Medication
Administration Training-New Hires on 2/28/23.
• Staff 2 does not have any discipline records in her
personnel file. Staff 2 completed Residential Medication
Administration Training-New Hires on 8/29/22.
8

Analysis The facility is found in violation as Staff 1 and Staff 2 left the
medication room door open, which left the medication cart
accessible to all youth in the home.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR2022C0228002 dated 8/23/22; CAP approved 9/14/22
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to Resident Ratio
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Additional Finding of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation On 4/12/23, interval checks on two youth who were out of direct
supervision of staff exceeded 15 minutes.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/14/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported staff are
supposed to complete every 15-minute checks when Youth B is in
her bedroom to ensure she’s alive and breathing. Depending on
the staff working or Youth B’s mood, Youth B reported sometimes
staff don’t always visually see her. Youth B stated sometimes staff
just do verbal checks by knocking on the door or opening the door
and asking, “are you okay?”. Youth B reported sometimes she
likes to sit in a closet in the dark, so staff don’t always visually
check on her in there either. Youth B reported staff conduct
bathroom checks by knocking on the door. If a youth responds to
staff’s inquiry if they’re okay, then staff leave. If a youth does not
respond or staff are concerned about a youth, they may force the
door open with a staff of the same gender as the youth to ensure
the youth’s safety. Youth B reported staff always check on her
every 15 minutes and it bothers her. Youth B has not had any
concerns with staff missing checks and is not aware of a time
when staff did not check on her within the timeframe required.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/18/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Youth C reported staff
always check on him visually, never just verbally. Youth C
reported staff conduct checks every 15 minutes and is not aware
of a time when staff did not check on him in the timeframes
required.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/18/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Chief Administrator sat
in on the interview as well. Staff 1 reported if youth are not on
precautions requiring increased checks, interval checks must be
9

completed every 15 minutes and staff must visually see the youth.
Staff 1 reported the checks should be done at staggered times,
rather than every 15 minutes exactly, so youth do not know staff
are coming to check on them. Staff 1 reported if a youth is in a
bad mood, slams their door, or asks for space in between the 15-
minute timeframes, staff might not open the door to check on a
youth and might verbally ask if the youth is okay, but every 15-
minute checks must always be eyes on. Staff 1 reported he
always fills out the check logs at the time of the checks and does
not wait to fill them out because he does not want to forget the
information. He reported he documents the time the check was
done and the location of the youth at the time of the check. Staff 1
reported he conducted 15-minute or less checks on Youth B and
Youth C while Staff 2 was outside of the home.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/18/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Chief Administrator sat
in on the interview as well. Staff 2 reported staff have interval
check log sheets for the youth they’re assigned to complete
checks on during their shift. If they check on other youth down the
same hall as their assigned youth, they need to let the other staff
know so it can be documented. Staff 2 reported she was assigned
to complete checks on Youth C on 4/12/23 but cannot remember
the other youth she was assigned to. Staff 2 reported she fills out
the log sheets at the time she’s doing the checks, so she does not
forget the information. Staff 2 reported checks must be completed
at deviated times within 15 minutes and not every 15 minutes on
the dot. Staff 2 reported if youth are in the milieu with staff, staff
will typically write the times as every 15 minutes exactly because
youth were within eyesight the entire time. If youth are outside of
staff’s eyesight, checks must be completed visually on the youth
within the 15-minute timeframes. Staff 2 reported when she left
the home, Staff 1 was responsible for checks on all youth. Staff 2
reported Youth A has 5-minute checks because they are on self-
harm/suicide precautions. Staff 2 reported she completed all
checks as required on 4/12/23.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/18/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Chief Administrator sat
in on the interview as well. Staff 3 reported staff are to conduct
interval checks by visually seeing as well as hearing youth. Staff 3
reported the checks are to be conducted by staff every 15 minutes
or less and should not be conducted every 15 minutes exactly
because it is predictable. Staff 3 reported Youth B and Youth C
required every 15-minute checks on 4/12/23, but Youth A required
5-minute checks due to being on self-harm precautions.
10

VIDEO REVIEWED
Video footage from the night of 4/12/23 was reviewed.
• Youth B entered her room at 8:14 pm, a bed check was first
completed at 8:36 pm (22 minutes), which was completed
by Staff 2. Youth B exited her room at 8:51 pm, re-enters
her room at 8:54 pm and then exited again at 8:57 pm
when she is provided with her medication by staff. Youth B
entered her room at 8:58 pm and exited at 9:07 pm to go
into the milieu. Youth B entered her room at 9:16 pm and
Staff 2 completed a bed check at 9:18 pm. Youth B remains
in her room and another bed check isn’t completed until
9:48 pm (30 minutes), which is completed by Staff 2. Youth
B remained in her room the rest of the night and does not
have a bed check completed between 9:49 pm-10:29 pm
(40 minutes). Staff 2 completed a bed check on Youth B at
10:30 pm.
• Youth C entered his room at 9:47 pm and Staff 2 completed
a bed check at 9:48 pm. Youth C remains in his room until
10:25 pm when he came out to request access to the
bathroom, which Staff 2 granted. A bed check was not
completed between 9:49 pm-10:25 pm (36 minutes).
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• DA Blodgett St. John’s Youth Supervision Procedure (rev.
6/2022) states staff will complete the Daily Observation
Record (DOR) for each youth they are responsible for. The
DOR will be handed off to a different staff when the
supervision responsibility changes. Staff must always keep
the DOR on their person and document the location of each
youth at varying intervals not to exceed 15 minutes.
Frequency of checks may be increased during precautions
or suicide status. Staff are responsible to always know
where youth are. During nighttime checks, staff must
observe the room to ensure youth are in their room and not
engaging in unsafe behavior.
• Youth B’s Daily Observation Record dated 4/12/23 states
Staff 1 completed a check at 8:15 pm and documented
Youth B was in the milieu, however, according to video
footage reviewed, Youth B was in her room. Staff 3
documented she completed a room check at 8:30,
however, according to video footage reviewed, it was Staff
2 who completed a room check and she completed it at
8:36 pm. Staff 2 documented she completed a room check
11

at 9:30 pm, however, according to video footage reviewed,
she did not. Staff 1 documented he completed a room
check at 9:45 pm, however, according to video footage
reviewed, Staff 2 completed a room check at 9:48 pm. Staff
1 documented he completed room checks at 10:00 pm and
10:15 pm, however, according to video footage reviewed,
these checks did not occur.
• Youth C’s Daily Observation Record dated 4/12/23 states
Staff 1 completed room checks at 10:00 pm and 10:15 pm,
however according to video footage reviewed, these
checks did not occur. Staff 2 documented she completed a
room check at 10:30 pm, but according to video footage
reviewed, she completed the check at 10:25 pm.
• Staff 1 did not have any discipline records in his personnel
file prior to this incident. On 4/18/23, Staff 1 was terminated
from the facility due to violation of policies and procedures
surrounding falsification of documentation for youth checks
and not following Youth A’s precautions and safety plan,
which resulted in Youth A participating in self-injurious
behavior. Staff 1 completed Supervision and Ratio policy
training on 3/23/23.
• Staff 2 does not have any discipline records in her
personnel file. Staff completed Supervision Scenario
Training on 8/25/22 and Supervision and Ratio policy
training on 3/23/23.
• Staff 3 does not have any discipline records in her
personnel file. Staff 3 completed Supervision Scenario
Training on 8/25/22, Suicide Screening for Direct Care Staff
on 11/15/22 and Supervision and Ratio policy training on
3/23/23.
Analysis The facility is found in violation as video footage reviewed showed
Youth B and Youth C did not have checks completed by staff as
required.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Facility should remove guided timeframes from the observation
logs to ensure staff are completing variable interval checks rather
than completing checks every 15 minutes exactly.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR 2022C0103016 dated 5/26/22; CAP approved 7/21/22
12

Rule Code & ACT 116 - 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination
Section of conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
Description department, bureau of fire services, or local authorities;
records; reports report; forms; confidentiality; disclosure of
information; availability of confidential records; child
information cards to be provided to department; failure of
licensee to cooperation with investigation, inspection or
examination.;
(1) The department may investigate, inspect, and examine
conditions of a childcare organization and may investigate
and examine the books and records of the licensee. The
licensee shall cooperate with the department’s
investigation, inspection, and examination by doing all of
the following:
(c) Providing accurate and truthful information to the
department, and encouraging witnesses, such as staff and
household members, to provide accurate and truthful
information to the department.
Violation Additional Finding of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff falsified documentation regarding interval checks conducted
on youth in the facility.
Investigation VIDEO REVIEWED:
Video footage from the night of 4/12/23 was reviewed, and the
times staff checked on youth were compared with the behavior
observation logs for Youth A, Youth B and Youth C. Those
comparisons are detailed in the documents reviewed section
below.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• Youth A’s Behavior Observation Log dated 4/12/23. Staff 1
documented Youth A was in the bathroom at 9:40 pm;
however according to video footage reviewed, Youth A was
